columns.text: In this problem, we will solve for the effective annual rate and the annual percentage rate based on the given data.

The annual percentage rate is the percentage that you are required to pay each year when loaning money. This includes not only the interest rate but also the corresponding fees. The formula for the annual percentage rate (APR) is given as:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Annual percentage rate}&=\text{Rate} \times \text{Time period} \times 100
\end{aligned}$$

The time period is basically the number of periods in a given year. So if the rate is given daily, then the time period will be 365 days and if the rate is given weekly, then the time period will be 52 weeks.

The effective annual rate measures the real return of a certain loan/savings when the amount is compounded over time. It can be solved using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Effective annual rate}&=[(1+\text{Rate})^\text{Time period}-1]\times 100
\end{aligned}$$

The time period is basically the number of periods in a given year. So if the rate is given daily, then the time period will be 365 days and if the rate is given weekly, then the time period will be 52 weeks.

**a.** Since the given rate is weekly, we will use time period of 52 weeks in solving for both the APR and EAR.

Solving for the APR, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{APR}&=0.068 \times52 \times 100\\[15 pt]
&=353.60\%
\end{aligned}$$

The store should report the annual percentage rate as $353.60\%$

For the EAR, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{EAR}&=[(1+0.068)^{52}-1] \times 100\\[15 pt]
&=2959.885\%
\end{aligned}$$

The store should report the effective annual rate as $2959.885\%$

**b.** In this problem, the discount rate is given. This means that we first need to solve for the weekly rate. In order to do this, we will first assume a $\$100$ loan. Since the discount rate is $6.80\%$, we will reduce $\$6.80$ from the loan. We will then be left with:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Actual value of loan}&=\$100-\$6.80\\[15pt]
&=\$93.20
\end{aligned}$$

From this, we can get the actual weekly rate using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Rate}&=\dfrac{\text{Initial value}}{\text{Actual value}}-1
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Rate}&=\dfrac{\$100}{\$93.20}-1\\[15 pt]
&=0.07296
\end{aligned}$$

This means that the weekly rate is $0.07296$

Since we now have the weekly rate, we can simply substitute this value to the formula for APR and EAR.

For APR:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{APR}&=0.07296 \times 52 \times 100\\[15 pt]
&=379.392\%
\end{aligned}$$

The APR now is at $379.392\%$

For the EAR:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{EAR}&=[(1+0.07296)^{52}-1] \times 100\\[15pt]
&=3793.531\%
\end{aligned}$$

The effective annual rate for this is $3793.531\%$

**c.** For this, we will now use the concept of internal rate of return (IRR) to get the rate that we will use to solve for the annual percentage rate and the effective annual rate. 

Internal rate of return refers to the rate of the return without including the external factors. In order to do this, we can use the IRR function of a spreadsheet utility.

To get the IRR, simply input the net loan amount, amount to be paid per week, and the number of installments. After doing so, simply type in $=\text{IRR}($ then highlight the three values before closing it with another parenthesis$)$.

Doing so will give us an IRR of $16.039\%$ or $0.16039$

Now that we have the rate, we can simply substitute this to the formula for APR and EAR.

For APR, we have:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{APR}&=0.16039 \times 52 \times 100\\[15 pt]
&=834.028\%
\end{aligned}$$

The APR for this is $834.028\%$

For the EAR, we have:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{EAR}&=[(1+0.16039)^{52}-1]\times 100\\[15 pt]
&=228,674.086\%
\end{aligned}$$

The effective annual rate is $228,674.086\%$
